annotation.text: Ordinance 04-795, which enacted this article, contained these uncodified provisions:
Section 3 {Catchlines and Comments} –

[T]he catchlines preceding and the comments following the various sections and subsections in this Ordinance are for guidance only. They are not law and may not be considered to have been enacted as a part of this Ordinance.
Section 5 {Initial Training} –

[E]ach official in office on the effective date of this Ordinance must complete the training course required by § 3-20 and file the affidavit required by § 3-21 within 6 months of the effective date of this Ordinance.
Section 6 {Codes of Conduct} –

para.text: The Codes of Conduct adopted by the Mayor (Executive Order dated June 13,1995), the City Council (Resolution 95-1279), and the Comptroller (July 14, 1995), having been specifically drafted to supplement the now-repealed provisions of former City Code Article 8, are repealed.

The Mayor, the City Council, the Comptroller, and all other agencies are encouraged to consult with the Ethics Board and develop, in accord with City Code Article 8, § 2-33(c), as enacted by this Ordinance, rules or regulations to supplement the statutory provisions governing conflicts of interest.

annotation.text: Section 7 {Initial Deadlines} –

[T]o avoid any undue burden that might result from the changes made by this Ordinance in reporting periods and filing deadlines for financial disclosure statements and lobbyist activity reports, the Board of Ethics may advance or delay, as appropriate, the filing deadline for the first statement or report to be filed after the effective date of this Ordinance and may shorten or lengthen, as appropriate, the reporting period for that first statement or report.
Section 9 {Effective Date} –
[T]his Ordinance takes effect on the later of (i) January 1, 2005, and (ii) the date on which this Ordinance is approved by the State Ethics Commission.
The State Ethics Commission approved the Ordinance on June 22, 2004. Accordingly, the new article became effective January 1, 2005.

para.heading: Trust in government essential.
para.text: The Mayor and City Council of Baltimore recognizes that our system of representative government largely depends on the people's trust in their public servants.

para.heading: Need for impartiality.
para.text: The citizens of Baltimore City rely on their public servants to preserve their safety, health, and welfare through fair and impartial enforcement of laws, imposition of taxes, and expenditure of public funds.

para.heading: Citizens' right of reliance.
para.text: Each citizen of Baltimore City has a right to be assured of the fair, impartial, and independent judgment of all public servants.

section.heading: Goals; purpose.
section.text: To guard against improper influence or even the appearance of improper influence, and to ensure public trust in the government, the Mayor and City Council of Baltimore enacts this article to:

para.text: set minimum ethical standards of conduct for City officials and employees;
require certain officials and employees to disclose their financial interests;
require persons engaged in lobbying activities to register and disclose those activities; and
generally protect the public welfare.

section.heading: Short title.
section.text: This article may be cited as the "Baltimore City Public Ethics Law".

section.heading: In general.
section.text: In this article, the following terms have the meanings indicated unless the context clearly requires a different meaning or a different definition is adopted for a particular statutory unit.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: "Agency" means any department, board, commission, council, authority, committee, office, or other unit of City government.

para.heading: Inclusions.
para.text: "Agency" also includes:
Baltimore Children and Youth Fund;
Baltimore City Parking Authority;
Baltimore Development Corporation;
Baltimore Police Department;
Enoch Pratt Free Library of Baltimore City;
Housing Authority of Baltimore City;
Local Development Council, South Baltimore Video Lottery Terminal;
Pimlico Community Development Authority;
South Baltimore Gateway Community Impact District Management Authority; and
any individual not embraced in a unit of City government who exercises authority comparable to that of the head of a unit of City government.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: "Board" means any board, commission, council, authority, committee, or other unit of City government that comprises 2 or more members, all of whom are appointed and serve on a part-time basis.

para.heading: Inclusions.
para.text: "Board" also includes:
Board of Commissioners of the Housing Authority of Baltimore City;
Board of Directors of the Baltimore Children and Youth Fund;
Board of Directors of the Baltimore City Parking Authority;
Board of Directors of the Baltimore Development Corporation;
Board of Directors of the South Baltimore Gateway Community Impact District Management Authority;
Civilian Review Board of Baltimore City;
Local Development Council, South Baltimore Video Lottery Terminal; and
Pimlico Community Development Authority.

section.heading: "Business entity".
section.text: "Business entity" means any person engaged in business or other organized activity, whether for-profit or not-for-profit and regardless of form.

section.heading: "Child".
section.text: "Child" means a biological child, adopted child, stepchild, ward, or foster child, regardless of age.

section.heading: "Compensation".
section.text: "Compensation" means any money or thing of value, regardless of form, received or to be received by a person for services rendered.

section.heading: "Elected official".
section.text: "Elected official" means:

para.text: the Mayor;
the City Comptroller;
the President of the City Council; and
any member of the City Council.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: "Employee" means any employee of the City who is not an official.

para.heading: Inclusions.
para.text: "Employee" also includes an employee of any agency or board included within the scope of § 2-2 {"Agency"} or § 2-3 {"Board"} of this subtitle.

section.heading: "Ethics Board".
section.text: "Ethics Board" means the Baltimore City Board of Ethics, established under Article VII, § 106 of the City Charter and Subtitle 3 {"Administration") of this article.

section.heading: "Executive Director".
section.text: "Executive Director" means the Executive Director of the Ethics Board or the Executive Director's designee.

section.heading: "Financial interest".
section.text: "Financial interest" means ownership of:

para.text: more than 3% of a business entity;
securities of any kind that represent or are convertible into ownership of more than 3% of a business entity; or
any interest as the result of which the owner:
received more than $1,000 in any 1 of the preceding 3 calendar years; or
is entitled to receive more than $1,000 in the current or any subsequent calendar year.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: "Gift" means, except as specified in subsection (b) of this section, the transfer of any thing or any service of economic value, regardless of the form, without adequate, identifiable, and lawful consideration.

para.heading: Exclusions.
para.text: "Gift" does not include the solicitation, acceptance, receipt, or disposition of a political contribution that is regulated under State Election Law Article, Title 13 {"Campaign Finance"} or under any other state law that regulates the conduct of elections or the receipt of political contributions.

annotations.annotation: For the Code-wide standard definition of “includes” and “including”, see City General Provisions Article, § 1-105.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: "Interest" means, except as specified in subsection (b) of this section, any legal or equitable economic interest, whether or not subject to an encumbrance or a condition, that is owned or held wholly or partly, jointly or severally, or directly or indirectly.

para.heading: Exclusions.
para.text: "Interest" does not include:
an interest held in the capacity of a personal representative, agent, custodian, fiduciary, or trustee, unless the holder has an equitable interest in the subject matter;
an interest in a time or demand deposit in a financial institution;

an interest in an insurance policy, endowment policy, or annuity contract under which an insurer promises to pay a fixed amount of money, either in a lump sum or periodically for life or some other specified period;

an interest in a mutual fund that is publicly traded on a national scale, unless the mutual fund is composed primarily of holdings of stocks and interests in a specific sector or area that is regulated by the public servant's agency;
an interest in a trust that is qualified under § 401 or § 501 of the Internal Revenue Code and forms part of a pension or a profit-sharing plan;
an interest in a qualified tuition plan under § 529 of the Internal Revenue Code; or

a mutual fund or exchange-traded fund that is publicly traded on a national scale unless the mutual fund or exchange-traded fund is composed primarily of holdings of stocks and interests in a specific sector or area that is regulated by the public servant's agency.

section.heading: "Lobbyist".
section.text: "Lobbyist" means any person required to register with the Ethics Board under Subtitle 8 {"Lobbying"} of this article.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: "Official" means:
an elected official;
the head of any department;
the head of any bureau or division within a department; and
any other individual in a unit of City government who, whether acting alone or as a member of a board acting jointly with other board members:
has authority comparable to that of the head of a department or the head of a bureau or division;
has decision-making authority in making City policy;
has decision-making authority in the exercise of quasi-judicial, regulatory, licensing, inspecting, or auditing functions; or
acts as a principal advisor to one who has authority of the type listed.

para.heading: Inclusions.
para.text: "Official" also includes the Chief Executive Officer, Chief Operating Officer, Chief Financial Officer, Executive Director, Executive Secretary, or Administrator of any agency or board included within the scope of § 2-2 {"Agency"} or § 2-3 {"Board"} of this subtitle.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: "Person" has the meaning stated in § 1-107(a) {"Person: In general"} of the City Code's General Provisions Article.

para.heading: Qualified inclusion of governmental entities.
para.text: Notwithstanding § 1-107(b) {"Person: Exclusion"} of the General Provisions Article, in this article "person" also includes, except as used in Subtitle 9 {"Enforcement"} for the imposition of criminal penalties, a governmental entity or an instrumentality or unit of a governmental entity.

section.heading: "Public servant".
section.text: "Public servant" means any official or employee.

section.heading: In general.
section.text: In interpreting and applying this article, the following rules of interpretation apply:

para.text: those contained in Subtitles 2 and 3 of the City Code's General Provisions Article; and
any additional rules contained in this Part II.

para.heading: Article sets minimum requirements.
para.text: In their interpretation and application, the provisions of this article must be taken to be the minimum requirements for the promotion of the public health, safety, and general welfare.

para.heading: Other laws.
para.text: If another applicable law relating to conflicts of interest, financial disclosure, or lobbying is more stringent than this article, that provision also applies.

para.heading: Agency rules and regulations.
para.text: If an agency adopts a rule or regulation relating to conflicts of interest that is more stringent than this article, that provision also applies.

section.heading: Liberal construction.
section.text: The Mayor and City Council intends that the provisions of this article, except those imposing criminal sanctions, be liberally construed to accomplish their purposes.

section.heading: Establishment.
section.text: There is a Baltimore City Board of Ethics, as established under Article VII, § 106 of the City Charter and this subtitle.

para.heading: Composition.
para.text: The Ethics Board comprises the following 5 members, appointed by the Mayor in accordance with City Charter Article IV, § 6:
1 member nominated by the President of the City Council;
1 member nominated by the City Comptroller; and
3 members named by the Mayor, at least 2 of whom must be members of the Maryland Bar.
Each member of the Ethics Board must be:
an individual of known personal integrity;
someone who possesses a recognized knowledge and interest in government and civics; and
a resident of the City of Baltimore.
No person may be appointed to the Board or, once appointed, continue to serve on the Board if the person:
is or becomes a lobbyist under the State Public Ethics Law, Subtitle 8 of this article, or the ethics code of any political subdivision of this State;

is or becomes an officer or employee of the State, the City, or any other political subdivision of the State, or of any of their respective agencies, instrumentalities, or other units (other than a State college, university, or other institution of higher education); or
is or becomes a candidate for elected public office of the State, the City, or any other political subdivision of the State.
In accordance with City Charter Article VII, § 108(a), the term of a member is 5 years.
The terms of the members are staggered as required by the terms for the members first appointed under the 2010 amendments to this subtitle.
At the end of a term, a member continues to serve until a successor is appointed and qualifies.
The Mayor may remove an appointed member as provided in City Charter Article IV, § 6, but only for the following causes:
neglect of duty;
misconduct in office;
a disability that makes the member unable to discharge the powers and duties of the office; or
a violation of this article.
Before seeking City Council approval for a removal, the Mayor must give the member:
written notice of the charges; and
an opportunity to reply to the charges.

annotation.text: Section 2 of Ordinance 10-272, which changed the composition and terms of the Board, provides for the following initial terms

para.text: the member nominated by the Council President shall be appointed for a term ending December 31, 2015;
the member nominated by the Comptroller shall be appointed for a term ending December 31, 2014; and
of the remaining 3 members:
1 shall be appointed for a term ending December 31, 2013;
1 shall be appointed for a term ending December 31, 2012; and
1 shall be appointed for a term ending December 31, 2011.
The Ethics Board must elect a Chair from among its members.
The term of the Chair is 1 year.
The Chair may be reelected.

para.heading: Others.
para.text: The Ethics Board may elect a Vice-Chair and other officers from among its members.

para.heading: Quorum.
para.text: 3 Members of the Ethics Board are a quorum.
An affirmative vote of at least 3 members is needed for any action by the Ethics Board.
The Board's records must show how each member voted on each question.

para.heading: Open meetings.
para.text: All meetings of the Ethics Board must be conducted in accordance with the State Open Meetings Act, Title 3 of the State General Provisions Article.

para.heading: Compensation; expenses.
para.text: The members of the Ethics Board:
serve without compensation; but
are entitled to reimbursement for reasonable expenses incurred in the performance of their duties, as provided in the Ordinance of Estimates.

para.heading: Rules and regulations.
para.text: Subject to Title 4 {"Administrative Procedure Act – Regulations"} of the City General Provisions Article, the Ethics Board may adopt rules and regulations to carry out the provisions of this article.

para.heading: Orders.
para.text: The Ethics Board may issue orders necessary or appropriate to carry out the provisions of this article.

annotations.annotation: By authority of Ordinance 20-431, Section 5, the Director of Legislative Reference, in consultation with the Law Department, has conformed the text of subsection (a) to refer to and reflect the requirements of the recently-enacted Administrative Procedure Act that, effective January 15, 2021, governs the proposal, adoption, and publication of administrative rules and regulations.

para.heading: Director.
para.text: The Inspector General serves as the Executive Director of the Ethics Board and is responsible for assisting the Board in performing its responsibilities.

para.heading: Staff.
para.text: In consultation with the Board, the Executive Director may assign staff from the Office of the Inspector General to assist the Board and Executive Director.

annotations.annotation: This section was amended by Ordinance 20-354, effective October 10, 2020, designating the Inspector General to serve ex officio as the Executive Director of the Ethics Board.

section.heading: Other assistance.
section.text: At the request of the Ethics Board, the Baltimore Police Department, City Solicitor, City Comptroller, and all other City officials and agencies must provide reasonable investigative or other professional assistance to the Board.

section.heading: Forms.
section.text: The Ethics Board must prepare and distribute all forms required by this article.

section.heading: Review of statements and reports.
section.text: As required by the Ethics Board from time to time, the Executive Director must:

para.text: review statements and reports filed in accordance with Subtitle 7 {"Financial Disclosure"} and Subtitle 8 {"Lobbying"} of this article; and
notify individuals who submit documents under those subtitles of any omissions or deficiencies.

para.heading: Board to maintain.
para.text: The Ethics Board must retain all documents filed with it and all other records of the Board for at least:
4 years; or
if longer, the period set by the Archives and Records Management Committee in consultation with the Ethics Board.

para.heading: Public access.
para.text: The Ethics Board must make these documents and other records available for public inspection and copying during regular office hours.

para.heading: Fees and procedures.
para.text: The Ethics Board may charge a reasonable fee for the examination and copying of documents or other records.

section.heading: Public awareness.
section.text: The Ethics Board must publish and make publicly available information that explains the provisions of this article, the duties imposed by it, and the means for enforcing it.

para.heading: Board to offer.
para.text: The Ethics Board must develop and offer a training course of not less than 2 hours on the requirements of this article.
Except as provided in paragraph (2) of this subsection, every official must complete the training course within 6 months of his or her appointment or reappointment to office.
The training requirements of this subsection do not apply to:
an official who, within the 3 years preceding his or her appointment or reappointment, completed a training course provided under this section; or
an individual who is an official only by virtue of being a board member, unless the board:
is one of the entities listed in § 7-8 {"[Disclosures statements] – Agency officials and staff"} of this article; or
performs one of the functions described in § 7-9 {"[Disclosure statements] – Procurement, legislative liaison, and enforcement personnel"} of this article.
After consultation with the Board, an agency head may authorize or require one or more classes of agency employees to attend the training course.
On request of the agency head, the Board must offer the training course to those employees as soon as practicable.
The Board must annually notify agency heads of the availability of the training course under this subsection.

para.heading: Assistance.
para.text: The Department of Human Resources must provide the Ethics Board with:
appropriate facilities for conducting the training course;
timely notice of the appointment of all officials subject to the training requirements; and
administrative and other assistance.

para.heading: Officials to file.
para.text: Each official must, within 6 months of his or her initial appointment to office, complete and file with the Ethics Board and with that official's appointing authority, an affidavit that certifies, under penalties of perjury, that the official:
has read and understands the provisions of this article governing conflicts of interest;
is not then in violation of those provisions; and
obligates himself or herself to comply with those provisions in all future activities.

para.heading: Form.
para.text: The affidavit must be in the form that the Ethics Board requires.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: The Ethics Board and Executive Director each may:
administer oaths; and
issue subpoenas for the attendance of witnesses to testify or to produce other evidence.

para.heading: Judicial enforcement.
para.text: A subpoena issued under this section may be judicially enforced.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: Except as otherwise specified in this article, the Ethics Board may charge reasonable filing fees for statements, reports, and other documents filed under this article.

para.heading: No fee for timely disclosure statement.
para.text: The Board may not charge a fee for a disclosure statement timely filed under Subtitle 7 {"Financial Disclosure"} of this article.

para.heading: Late fees.
para.text: The fees charged may include late fees for any document that is filed after the applicable deadline.

para.heading: General – Notice required.
para.text: An individual who is appointed to fill a vacancy in a position must be given written notice, in a form approved by the Ethics Board, of the requirements of:
§ 3-20 {"Training courses"};
§ 3-21 {"Conflicts affidavit"}; and
§ 7-12 {"Financial Disclosure: Appointee to vacancy"}.
For Board members and uncompensated appointees of the Mayor, the notice required by subsection (a) of this section must be given by the Mayor or the Mayor's designee.
For all other appointees, the notice must be given by the appointee's agency head or the agency head's designee.

para.heading: General – When to be given.
para.text: The notice required by subsection (a) of this section must be given within 5 days after the appointment.

To evidence receipt by the appointee and understanding of the appointee's responsibilities, the notice required by subsection (a) must be signed by both the appointee and the official providing the appointee the notice.
Within 5 days of signing, a copy of the signed notice required under this subsection must be:
placed in the appointee's agency personnel file; and
provided to the Ethics Board.

An individual who is nominated to fill a vacancy on a City board must also be given written notice, in a form approved by the Ethics Board, of the provisions of § 6-14 {"Exceptions – New board members"} of this article.
The notice required by paragraph (1) of this subsection must be given by the Mayor or the Mayor's designee at least 14 days before the appointment is to be confirmed.

annotations.annotation: Subsection (d) was added by Ordinance 19-287, effective February 25, 2020.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: The Ethics Board may exempt from this article, or modify the applicability of this article to, a board or 1 or more members of a board if the Ethics Board determines that, because of the nature of the board, the application of this article to the board or member:
would significantly reduce the availability of qualified individuals for public service; and
is not needed to preserve the purposes of this article.

para.heading: Written request required.
para.text: An exemption under this section may be granted only on the written request of the board involved.

section.heading: Reports.
section.text: The Ethics Board must submit to the Mayor and the City Council:

para.text: an annual report on its activities; and
as appropriate from time to time, based on its investigations and studies, special reports with recommendations for legislation.

para.heading: Requester's right.
para.text: At the written request of a person who is subject to this article, the Ethics Board must provide an advisory opinion, in a timely fashion, on the article's application to that person under the circumstances described in the request.

para.heading: Board's discretion.
para.text: At the written request of any person not within the scope of subsection (a) of this section, the Ethics Board may provide that person with an advisory opinion on the article's application to the circumstances described in the request.

para.heading: Requester's right.
para.text: The Executive Director must assist any person who needs or asks for help in preparing a written request under §4-1(a) {"Request for opinion: Requester's right"} of this subtitle.

para.heading: Director's discretion.
para.text: The Executive Director may assist any person who needs or asks for help in preparing a written request under §4-1(b) {"Request for opinion: Executive Director's discretion"} of this subtitle.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: Each advisory opinion of the Ethics Board must be:
in writing; and
subject to the redactions required by subsection (b) of this section, filed and made available for public inspection.
Neither the Ethics Board nor its staff may reveal the identity of the person that is the subject of an advisory opinion.
Before an advisory opinion is made public, the Ethics Board must delete:
the name of the person that is the subject of the opinion; and
to the fullest extent possible, any other information that might identify that person.

section.heading: Reliance on opinion.
section.text: Any person subject to this article is entitled to rely on an advisory opinion of the Ethics Board that:

para.text: is reasonably applicable to that person's circumstances; and
has not been:
overruled by a later opinion of the Ethics Board; or
superseded by an amendment to the applicable provisions of this article or of the rules and regulations adopted under it.
Any person may file a complaint with the Ethics Board alleging a violation of this article.
A complaint filed under this subsection must be:
in writing;
under oath; and
signed by the complainant.

para.heading: On Board's motion.
para.text: On its own motion, the Ethics Board may issue a written complaint alleging a violation of this article.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: Subject to the redactions required by subsection (b) of this section, the Executive Director must promptly send the respondent a copy of the complaint.

para.heading: Confidentiality.
para.text: For a complaint filed under § 5-1(a) {"Commencement of action: On complaint of other"} of this subtitle, the Executive Director must delete from the copy sent to the respondent:
the complainant's name; and
to the fullest extent possible, any other information that might identify the complainant.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: The Executive Director must promptly investigate the complaint.

para.heading: Report to Board.
para.text: The Executive Director must report his or her findings to the Ethics Board within a reasonable time.

para.heading: Opportunity to cure.
para.text: If the investigation discloses a prima facie violation, the Executive Director must:
so notify the respondent; and
provide the respondent with an opportunity to cure the violation.

para.heading: Dismissal on cure.
para.text: The Ethics Board may dismiss the complaint if:
within 15 days after the Executive Director's notice, the respondent cures the alleged violation; and
the Board finds that a dismissal would not be contrary to the purposes of this article.

para.heading: Notice of dismissal.
para.text: If the Ethics Board dismisses a complaint under this section, the Executive Director promptly must notify the complainant and respondent of the dismissal.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: After receiving the report of the investigation, if the Ethics Board determines that the facts do not merit further proceedings, the Board must dismiss the complaint.

para.heading: Notice of dismissal.
para.text: If the Ethics Board dismisses a complaint under this section, the Executive Director promptly must notify the complainant and respondent of the dismissal.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: If the complaint is not dismissed under § 5-4 {"Dismissal on cure of violation"} or § 5-5 {"Dismissal on preliminary review"} of this subtitle, the Ethics Board must provide the respondent with notice and an opportunity for a hearing before the Board.

para.heading: Representation by counsel.
para.text: At the hearing, the respondent is entitled to be represented by counsel.

para.heading: Procedures.
para.text: In its rules and regulations, the Ethics Board must establish procedures to govern the conduct of hearings held under this subtitle.

annotations.annotation: The procedures established by the Board to govern the conduct of hearings are set forth in Board Regulations R 05.21 through R 05.26.

para.heading: Determination.
para.text: After the Ethics Board considers all of the evidence presented, it must make written findings of fact and conclusion of law on each alleged violation.

para.heading: Finding of no violation.
para.text: If the Ethics Board determines that the respondent has not violated this article, the Board must:
dismiss the complaint; and
promptly notify the complainant and respondent of the dismissal.

para.heading: Sanctions for violation.
para.text: If the Ethics Board determines that the respondent has violated any provision of this article, the Board may take any 1 or more of the actions authorized in Subtitle 9 {"Enforcement"}, Part II {"Administrative Sanctions"}.

para.heading: Judicial review.
para.text: A respondent aggrieved by a final decision of the Ethics Board under this subtitle may seek judicial review of that decision by petition to the Circuit Court for Baltimore City in accordance with the Maryland Rules of Procedure.

para.heading: Appellate review.
para.text: A party to the judicial review may appeal the court's final judgment to the Court of Special Appeals in accordance with the Maryland Rules of Procedure.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: Notwithstanding any other law and except as otherwise provided in this section, after a complaint is filed:
the proceedings, meetings, and activities of the Ethics Board and its staff relating to the complaint are confidential; and
neither the Ethics Board nor its staff may disclose any information relating to the complaint, including the identity of the complainant or the respondent.
The Ethics Board may release any information, other than the complainant's identity, if the respondent has agreed in writing to the release.
The Ethics Board may disclose the complainant's identity to the respondent only at the respondent's request and for good cause shown.

para.heading: Duration.
para.text: The restrictions imposed by this section terminate when:
the matter is referred for criminal prosecution; or
the Ethics Board determines that a violation has occurred.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: In this subtitle, the following terms have the meanings indicated.

para.heading: Disqualifying relative.
para.text: "Disqualifying relative", as applied to an individual, means that individual's spouse, parent, child, or sibling.

para.heading: "Business entity" limited.
para.text: In this section, "business entity" does not include Baltimore City or any instrumentality, unit, or agency of Baltimore City.

para.heading: When participation prohibited.
para.text: Except as otherwise provided in this Part II, a public servant may not participate in and must disqualify himself or herself from any matter if:
the public servant has an interest in the matter of which the public servant might reasonably be expected to know;
to the public servant's knowledge, a disqualifying relative has an interest in the matter; or
any of the following is a party to the matter:
any business entity in which:
the public servant has a financial interest of which the public servant might reasonably be expected to know; or
to the public servant's knowledge, a disqualifying relative has a financial interest;
any business entity in which:
the public servant is a partner, officer, director, trustee, employee, or agent; or
to the public servant's knowledge, a disqualifying relative is a partner, officer, director, trustee, employee, or agent;
any business entity with which:
the public servant has applied for a position, is negotiating employment, or has arranged prospective employment; or
to the public servant's knowledge, a disqualifying relative has applied for a position, is negotiating employment, or has arranged prospective employment;
any business entity that is a party to a contract with:
the public servant, if the contract could reasonably be expected to result in a conflict between the private interests of the public servant and the public servant's official City duties; or

to the public servant's knowledge, a disqualifying relative, if the contract could reasonably be expected to result in a conflict between the private interests of the public servant or disqualifying relative and the public servant's official City duties;

any business entity in which a financial interest is held by another business entity in which the public servant has a financial interest, if the public servant might reasonably be expected to know of both financial interests;

any business entity in which a financial interest is held by another business entity in which a disqualifying relative has a financial interest, if the public servant knows of both financial interests;

any business entity that has a financial interest in another business entity in which the public servant also has a financial interest, if the public servant might reasonably be expected to know of both financial interests;

any business entity that has a financial interest in another business entity in which a disqualifying relative also has a financial interest, if the public servant knows of both financial interests; or

any business entity that, to the public servant's knowledge, is a creditor or obligee of the public servant or a disqualifying relative and that, as a creditor or obligee, is in a position to affect directly and substantially the interest of the public servant or disqualifying relative.

annotation.text: Section 8 of Ordinance 04-795 provides that the preceding § 6-6 “do[es] not prohibit the continued employment of a relative of a public servant if

para.text: the employment was entered into prior to the enactment of this Ordinance; and

immediately prior to the enactment of this Ordinance, the employment and the public servant's participation in the employment conformed to all then-applicable laws, rules, and other standards of conduct."

para.heading: In general.
para.text: Except as otherwise provided in subsection (b) of this section, a former lobbyist who is or becomes subject to regulation under this subtitle as an official may not participate in a case, contract, or other specific matter as an official for 1 calendar year after the termination of the former lobbyist's registration if the former lobbyist previously assisted or represented another party for compensation in that case, contract, or other specific matter.

para.heading: Board members.
para.text: This section does not apply to a former lobbyist who is an official only as a member of a board.

para.heading: Actions authorized by Board or article.
para.text: The prohibitions in § 6-6 {"Prohibited participation"} of this subtitle do not apply to the extent that participation in a matter is expressly allowed:
by a rule or regulation of the Ethics Board;
by an advisory opinion of the Ethics Board; or
by another provision of this article.

para.heading: Ministerial activities.
para.text: The prohibitions in § 6-6 {"Prohibited participation"} of this subtitle do not prohibit the exercise of a ministerial duty that does not affect the disposition of or any decision relating to the matter involved.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: Subject to subsection (b) of this section, a public servant who otherwise would be disqualified under § 6-6 {"Prohibited participation"} of this subtitle may nonetheless participate in a matter if:
his or her disqualification would leave a board or other body with less than a quorum capable of acting;
the public servant is required by law to act; or
the public servant is the only individual authorized to act.
A public servant who seeks to participate in a matter under the authority of this section must comply with the requirements of this subsection.
If acting as a member of a board or other body, the public servant must, before participating, publicly disclose to that board or other body the nature and circumstances of the conflict.

In all cases, the public servant must, as soon as possible after participating, file with the Ethics Board and the public servant's appointing authority a written notice of the nature and circumstances of the conflict and the participation.

section.heading: Service with entity on City's behalf.
section.text: The prohibitions in § 6-6 {"Prohibited participation"} of this subtitle do not apply to the service of a public servant as a trustee or director of a business entity doing business with or subject to regulation by the City as long as:

para.text: the City has an economic or programmatic interest in the entity; and
the public servant:
serves on the entity as part of his or her official duties, at the direction of his or her agency;
receives no fee, salary, or other remuneration for his or her service; and
does not participate in any matter in which the public servant or any disqualifying relative has a financial interest.

section.heading: Prohibited employment, interests.
section.text: Except as otherwise provided in this Part III, a public servant may not:

para.text: be employed by or have a financial interest in any person that is subject to the authority of that public servant or of the City agency with which the public servant is affiliated;
be employed by or have a financial interest in any person that is negotiating or has entered into:
a contract with the City or an agency of the City, if:
the contract is with, for the benefit of, or to be administered by the agency with which the public servant is affiliated;

the public servant's duties for the City include matters substantially relating to or affecting the subject matter of the contract and the contract binds or purports to bind the City to pay more than $1,000; or

for any other contract, the public servant fails to timely disclose to the Ethics Board and the procuring agencies, as required by rule or regulation of the Ethics Board, his or her employment by or financial interest in the person who is negotiating or has entered into the contract; or
a subcontract on a contract described in this item (2); or
hold any other employment relationship that would impair the impartiality and independent judgment of the public servant.

annotation.text: Section 2 of Ordinance 15-374 provides that the preceding § 6-11(2), as amended by Ord. 15-374, “does not prohibit continued employment or financial interest if

para.text: the employment or financial interest was entered into before the enactment of this Ordinance; and

the employment or financial interest did not violate then-§ 6-11, as in effect before the enactment of this Ordinance, and conformed to all other then-applicable laws, rules, and standards of conduct."

annotation.text: Ord. 15-374 was enacted and became immediately effective on June 11, 2015.

section.heading: Exceptions – Board regulation.
section.text: The prohibitions in § 6-11 {"Prohibited interests"} of this subtitle do not apply to an employment or financial interest that is allowed by a rule or regulation of the Ethics Board if:

para.text: in the case of employment, the employment does not create a conflict of interest or the appearance of a conflict of interest; and
in the case of a financial interest, the interest is disclosed in the manner required by the rule or regulation.

annotations.annotation: Board Regulation R 06.12.1 establishes exemptions under this § 6-12 for: (i) outside employment as an adjunct faculty member of an accredited college or university; and (ii) a board member appointed under a requirement that the member represent certain industries, classes, etc. Regulation R 06.12.2, in turn, provides for certain additional employment exemptions that, subject to certain criteria, may be approved by the Board on individual application.

section.heading: Exceptions – Industry representatives.
section.text: The prohibitions in § 6-11 {"Prohibited interests"} of this subtitle do not apply to an individual who is appointed to a regulatory or licensing unit pursuant to a requirement that persons subject to the jurisdiction of the unit be represented in appointments to it.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: The prohibitions in § 6-11 {"Prohibited interests"} of this subtitle do not apply to a board member who holds the employment or financial interest at the time of his or her appointment, if that employment or financial interest is publicly disclosed to the appointing authority, the Ethics Board, and, if applicable, the City Council before confirmation.

para.heading: Disclosure by affidavit.
para.text: The disclosure must be made by an affidavit, under penalties of perjury, in the form that the Ethics Board requires.

section.heading: Exceptions – Service on City's behalf.
section.text: The prohibitions in § 6-11 {"Prohibited interests"} of this subtitle do not apply to the service of a public servant as a trustee or director of a business entity in accord with and subject to the limitations specified in § 6-9 {"Service ... on City's behalf"} of this subtitle.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: Subject to subsection (b) of this section, the Ethics Board may exempt a public servant from the prohibitions of § 6-11 {"Prohibited interests"} of this subtitle or modify the applicability of those prohibitions to a public servant if the Board determines that failure to grant the exemption or modification would limit the City's ability to:
recruit and hire highly qualified or uniquely qualified professionals for public service; or
assure the availability of competent services to the public.
The Ethics Board may grant an exemption or modification under this section only:
in extraordinary circumstances;
at the request of the City agency involved; and
with the Mayor's approval of that request.
The Ethics Board must apply this section as consistently as possible under similar facts and circumstances.

section.heading: Permitted transactions.
section.text: The prohibitions of § 6-11 {"Prohibited interests"} of this subtitle do not prevent:

para.text: an elected official from appearing, without compensation, before any City agency or legislative body on behalf of constituents or in the performance of any public, official, or civic obligation or duty;

a public servant from accepting or receiving any benefit or facility that is provided for or made available to citizens or residents under any housing or other general welfare legislation or in the exercise of the police power, but only if the public servant does not exercise any responsibility or authority with respect to authorizing that benefit or facility for himself or herself; or
a public servant from entering into a contract with the City for the City's acquisition of real property, if:
the amount to be paid for the property does not exceed the property's value, as established by at least 2 competent real estate appraisers selected by the City; and
all records of the City relating to the transaction are open to public inspection at all times during regular business hours.

section.heading: Contingent compensation.
section.text: A public servant may not assist or represent a party for contingent compensation in any matter before or involving any City agency.

para.heading: Former public servants generally.
para.text: After leaving office or terminating employment, a former public servant may not assist or represent a party, other than the City, in a case, contract, or other specific matter for compensation if:
the matter involves City government; and
the former public servant significantly participated in the same matter as a public servant.

para.heading: Additional restrictions on former elected officials.

para.text: Except as provided in paragraph (2) of this subsection, a former elected official may not assist or represent another party for compensation in any matter that is the subject of legislative action for 1 calendar year from the date the elected official leaves office.
Paragraph (1) of this subsection does not apply to a former elected official's representation of a municipal corporation, county, or State governmental entity.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: Except as permitted under subsection (b) of this section, a public servant may not solicit or facilitate the solicitation of a gift, whether on the public servant's own behalf or on behalf of another person, from any person that the public servant knows or has reason to know:
does or seeks to do business of any kind, regardless of amount:
with the public servant's agency; or
with another person in connection with or in furtherance of a contract that is being negotiated or has been entered into by the other person with the public servant's agency;
engages or seeks to engage in an activity that is regulated or controlled by the public servant's agency;
is or, within the preceding 12 months, has been a lobbyist with respect to matters within the jurisdiction of the public servant;

has a financial interest that might be substantially and materially affected, in a manner distinguishable from the public generally, by the performance or nonperformance of the public servant's official duties; or
is an owner, partner, officer, director, trustee, employee, or agent of any person described in items (1) through (4) of this subsection.

para.heading: Exception.
para.text: The prohibition in subsection (a) of this section does not apply to a solicitation if:
it is for the benefit of an official governmental program or activity or a City-endorsed charitable function or activity; and
it either:
is expressly allowed by a rule or regulation of the Ethics Board; or
otherwise has been approved in advance by the Ethics Board, on the written request of the public servant and his or her agency.

annotations.annotation: Board Regulations R 06.26.1 and R 06.26.2 sets out criteria for obtaining approval under § 6-26(b) for “official governmental” or “City-endorsed charitable” solicitations.

section.heading: Acceptance prohibited.
section.text: Except as otherwise provided in this Part IV, a public servant may not knowingly accept any gift, directly or indirectly, from any person that the public servant knows or has reason to know:

para.text: does or seeks to do business of any kind, regardless of amount:
with the public servant's agency; or
with another person in connection with or in furtherance of a contract that is being negotiated or has been entered into by the other person with the public servant's agency;
engages or seeks to engage in an activity that is regulated or controlled by the public servant's agency;
is or, within the preceding 12 months, has been a lobbyist with respect to matters within the jurisdiction of the public servant;

has a financial interest that might be substantially and materially affected, in a manner distinguishable from the public generally, by the performance or nonperformance of the public servant's official duties; or
is an owner, partner, officer, director, trustee, employee, or agent of any person described in items (1) through (4) of this section.

section.heading: Qualified exemptions.
section.text: Subject to § 6-29 {"Exemption limitations"} of this subtitle, the prohibitions in § 6-27 {"Acceptance prohibited"} of this subtitle do not apply to the unsolicited receipt of:

para.text: food or beverages received and consumed by the recipient in the presence of the donor or sponsoring entity;
gifts or awards that have insignificant monetary value, as defined by rule or regulation of the Board;

in return for a speaking engagement or participation on a panel at a meeting, reasonable expenses, actually incurred and verifiable, for food, travel, lodging, child or dependant care, and scheduled entertainment of the public servant, but only if:
the expenses are associated with the meeting; and
to the extent the expenses are anticipated to exceed $500, the public servant has notified the Ethics Board before attending the meeting;

tickets or free admission given to an elected official to attend a specific charitable, cultural, or political event, if given by the person sponsoring or conducting the event as a courtesy or ceremony to the office;

a specific gift or class of gifts that the Ethics Board exempts on a written finding that acceptance of the gift or class of gifts would not be detrimental to the impartial conduct of City business; or
gifts from a spouse, parent, child, or sibling.

annotations.annotation: Board Regulation R 06.28.5 establishes exemptions under this § 6-28(5) (i) for certain pharmaceutical samples given to City health-care facilities, (ii) for certain free admissions to events sponsored or conducted by educational institutions, and (iii) for certain free admissions offered by or on behalf of an instrumentality or unit of State government.

Board Regulation R 06.28A defines “insignificant value”, for purposes of this section, as: “(1) a gift or award with a value of not more than $20; or (2) a gift or award in a series of gifts and awards with a cumulative value of not more than $60, if given by or on behalf of the same person during the reporting period.”

section.heading: Exemption limitations.
section.text: The exemptions specified in § 6-28 {"Qualified exemptions"} of this subtitle do not apply to any gift if:

para.text: the gift would tend to impair the recipient's impartiality and independent judgment; or
for a gift of significant value, as defined by rule or regulation of the Board:
the gift would give the appearance of impairing the recipient's impartiality and independent judgment; or
the recipient believes or has reason to believe that the gift is designed to impair his or her impartiality and independent judgment.

annotations.annotation: Board Regulation R 06.28B defines “significant value”, for purposes of § 6-29(2), as: “(1) any gift with a value of more than $20; or (2) a gift in a series of gifts with a cumulative value of more than $60, if given by or on behalf of the same person during the reporting period.”

section.heading: Additional exemptions by Board.
section.text: By rule or regulation, the Ethics Board may establish further exemptions from or modifications of this Part IV, as the Board considers necessary.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: A public servant may not intentionally use the prestige of his or her office or position for his or her own private gain or that of another.

para.heading: Constituent services.
para.text: The performance of usual and customary constituent services, without additional compensation, is not prohibited by this section.

section.heading: Disclosing confidential information.
section.text: Except in the discharge of an official duty, a public servant may not disclose or use, for his or her own economic benefit or that of another, confidential information that the public servant acquired by reason of his or her public position and that is not available to the public.

para.heading: Scope of section.
para.text: This section applies to:

any individual who, for a proposed City procurement, assists a City agency in the drafting, development, or issuance of specifications, an invitation for bids, a request for proposals, a request for qualifications, or any other document related to the procurement; and
any person who employs that individual.

para.heading: Prohibited conduct.
para.text: A person described in subsection (a) of this section may not:
submit a response for that procurement; or
directly or indirectly, assist or represent another person in submitting a response for that procurement.

para.heading: Exemptions.
para.text: For purposes of this section, the following transactions do not constitute assisting in the drafting of specifications, an invitation for bids, a request for proposals, or a request for qualifications:
providing descriptive literature, such as catalogue sheets, brochures, technical data sheets, or standard specification "samples", whether solicited by the City agency or unsolicited;

submitting written comments on a specification prepared by an agency or on a solicitation for a bid or proposal, if comments have been solicited from 2 or more persons as part of a request for information or a prebid or preproposal process; or
providing specifications for a sole-source or selected-source procurement authorized by law.

section.heading: Employment of relatives by elected officials.

para.heading: "Relative" defined.
para.text: In this section, "relative" means:
spouse;
parent or stepparent;
sibling or step sibling;
child, stepchild, foster child, or ward;
mother-in-law or father-in-law;
son-in-law or daughter-in-law;
grandparent; or
grandchild.

para.heading: Prohibited employment.
para.text: No elected official may use public funds to employ a relative of that elected official or of any other elected official.

annotation.text: Section 8 of Ordinance 04-795 provides that the preceding § 6-39 “do[es] not prohibit the continued employment of a relative of a public servant if

para.text: the employment was entered into prior to the enactment of this Ordinance; and

immediately prior to the enactment of this Ordinance, the employment and the public servant's participation in the employment conformed to all then-applicable laws, rules, and other standards of conduct."

annotation.text: The Ordinance was enacted on July 8, 2004.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: In this subtitle, "business with the City" means any 1 or combination of sales, purchases, leases, or contracts:
that are made:
to, from, or with the City or an agency of the City; or
to, from, or with another person in connection with or in furtherance of a contract that is being negotiated or has been entered into by the other person with the City or an agency of the City; and
involve consideration of $5,000 or more on a cumulative basis.

para.heading: Determining consideration.
para.text: For purposes of this section, the total consideration committed to be paid as of the award or execution of a contract or lease, to the extent then ascertainable, is included, regardless of the period over which payments are to be made.

para.heading: Agencies to identify those required to file.
Newly-created or vacant positions.
para.text: Prior to filling a newly-created or vacant position:
each agency head must identify whether the position will be required to file a statement under this subtitle; and
if the agency head identifies the position as being required to file a statement under this subtitle, each agency head must:
include a disclosure of the financial disclosure requirement in any advertisement or job listing seeking applicants for that position; and
provide the Board with the appointee's name and position number within 10 days of filling that position.

para.heading: Annual reporting.
para.text: On or before January 1 of each year, each agency head must provide to the Ethics Board, with a copy to the Director of Human Resources, the names and position numbers of all public servants in that agency who are required to file statements with the Ethics Board under:
§ 7-7 { "Elected officials and staff"};
§ 7-8 {"Agency officials and staff"}; or
§ 7-9 {"Procurement, legislative liaison, and enforcement personnel"}.

para.heading: HR supplemental list.
para.text: On or before February 1 of each year, the Director of Human Resources must provide to the Ethics Board the names and position numbers of all public servants who:
hold positions of the types described in § 7-9 {"Procurement, legislative liaison, and enforcement personnel"} of this subtitle; and
are not identified on any of the agency lists submitted under subsection (a) of this section.

para.heading: Entities doing business with City.
para.text: On or before February 1 of each year, the Finance Department must post on its website a searchable list of all persons that did business with the City for the calendar year immediately preceding the current calendar year.

para.heading: Registered lobbyists.
para.text: On or before February 1 of each year, the Ethics Board must post on its website a searchable list of all lobbyists who have registered with the Board for the calendar year immediately preceding the current calendar year.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: Except as otherwise specified in this subtitle, each statement must be filed with the Ethics Board on or before April 30 of each year.

para.heading: Elected officials.
para.text: Elected officials must file the statement required by this subtitle on or before January 31 of each year.

para.heading: Reporting period; information.
para.text: Except as otherwise specified in this subtitle:
each statement must cover the calendar year immediately preceding the filing; and
disclose for that year all of the information required by Part III {"Contents of Statements"} of this subtitle.

para.heading: Form.
para.text: Each statement must be:
filed on the form the Ethics Board provides; and
signed under oath or affirmation, subject to the penalties of perjury.

section.heading: Statement by official of proposed action.
section.text: An official must disclose employment and interests that raise a potential conflict of interest in connection with a specific proposed action by the official. The disclosure must be made sufficiently in advance of the action to provide adequate disclosure to the public.

annotations.annotation: Board Regulation R 07.03 sets out how and to whom the disclosure required by this section must be made.

para.text: Except as provided in paragraph (2) of this subsection, the Ethics Board shall allow a person to inspect a financial disclosure filed by a public servant under this subtitle.
The Ethics Board may not provide public access to a portion of a statement that is filed on or after January 1, 2019, and that expressly identifies an individual's home address.

para.heading: Record of inspections.
para.text: The Executive Director must:
require each person who inspects a statement filed under this subtitle to identify him- or herself; and
record:
the inspecting person's name, address, telephone number, and organization represented; and
the name of the person whose statement was inspected.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: In this Part II, the following terms have the meanings indicated.

para.heading: "Non-clerical employee".
para.text: "Non-clerical employee" means any public servant who:
is compensated for his or her services; and
is not employed solely in a secretarial, clerical, or custodial capacity.
