section.heading: Persons required to file – Procurement, legislative liaison, and enforcement personnel.
section.text: The following public servants must file the financial disclosure statements required by this subtitle:

para.heading: Procurement employees.
para.text: All non-clerical employees whose functions include:

the drafting, development, or issuance of specifications, invitations for bids, requests for proposals, requests for qualifications, or other related documents for the procurement of supplies, materials, or services;
the review or evaluation of bids, proposals, qualifications, or contracts for the procurement of supplies, materials, or services; or
the inspection, monitoring, or other enforcement of contract standards and specifications.

para.heading: Legislative liaisons.
para.text: All public servants whose functions include the influence of legislative action, as defined in § 8-1 of this article.

para.heading: Enforcement personnel.
para.text: All other public servants whose official duties include enforcement of (including inspections to assure compliance with) laws, rules, or regulations that affect the rights of the public or the procedures available to the public.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: Except as provided in subsection (d) of this section, an individual who, other than by reason of death, vacates a position for which an annual statement is required must file a departure statement with the Ethics Board.

para.heading: When to be filed.
para.text: The departure statement must be filed within 60 days after vacating the position.

para.heading: Scope of statement.
para.text: The departure statement must:
be in the form and contain all of the information required for an annual statement; and
cover a reporting period that includes:
the calendar year immediately preceding the date of vacating the position, unless the individual already has filed an annual statement for that year; and
the part of the current calendar year during which the individual served.

para.heading: Exceptions.
para.text: A departure statement need not be filed if:
an individual vacates a position to assume another position for which an annual statement is required under this subtitle; and
the disclosure requirements of the new position are at least as extensive as those of the former position.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: Except as provided in subsection (d) of this section, an individual who is appointed to fill a vacancy in a position for which an annual statement is required must file an entry statement with the Ethics Board.

para.heading: When to be filed.
para.text: The entry statement must be filed within 30 days after the appointment.

para.heading: Scope.
para.text: The entry statement must:
be in the form and contain all of the information required for an annual statement; and
cover the calendar year immediately preceding the appointment.

para.heading: Exceptions.
para.text: An entry statement need not be filed if:
while in another position, the individual already filed an annual statement for the preceding calendar year; and
the disclosure requirements of the former position were at least as extensive as those of the new position.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: Except as provided in subsection (b) of this section, a candidate for an elected office for which an annual statement is required must file a statement annually:
beginning with the year in which the candidate files a certificate of candidacy; and
continuing through the year of the election.

para.heading: Exception.
para.text: This section does not require the filing of a statement for any full year that is already covered by a statement the individual has otherwise filed under this subtitle.

para.heading: Filing requirements — Place.
para.text: The statement required by this section must be filed with the Baltimore City Board of Elections.
The initial statement required by this section must be filed no later than with the filing of the certificate of candidacy.
In each subsequent year, through and including the year of the election, the statement must be filed on or before the earlier of:
April 30; or
the last day for the withdrawal of a candidacy under State Election Law Article, § 5-502.

para.heading: Filing requirements – Contents.
para.text: The disclosure requirements applicable to a candidate filing under this section are the same as those applicable to an incumbent holding the office involved.

para.heading: Filing prerequisite to candidacy.
para.text: The Board of Elections may not accept a certificate of candidacy of a candidate covered by this section unless the candidate has filed the initial statement required by subsection (d)(1) of this section.

para.heading: Subsequent failure to file.
para.text: If a later statement required by this section is overdue and is not filed within 20 days after the candidate receives from the Board of Elections written notice of the failure to file, the candidate is considered to have withdrawn his or her candidacy.

para.heading: Forwarding to Ethics Board.
para.text: Within 30 days after receiving a statement, the Board of Supervisors of Elections must forward the statement to the Ethics Board.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: Individuals designated under this section, other than elected officials, may also be required to disclose information annually.

para.heading: Designations — by Mayor.
para.text: By executive order, the Mayor may designate for disclosures under this section:
any employee of an executive agency; and
any uncompensated appointee of the Mayor.

para.heading: Designations — by City Council President.
para.text: By written order, the President of the City Council may designate for disclosures under this section:
any employee of the City Council; and
any uncompensated appointee of the President.

para.heading: Contents.
para.text: An individual filing a statement under this section must include the relevant information that the applicable designating authority specifies.

para.heading: Statement a public record.
para.text: A statement filed under this section is a public record.

section.heading: In general.
section.text: The statement required to be filed under this subtitle must include schedules that disclose the information and interests specified in this Part III, as directly applicable to the public servant or attributable to the public servant for the reporting period for which the statement is required.

annotations.annotation: Board Regulation 07.16 authorizes board members who are not otherwise officials or employees required to file disclosure statements to file a modified, more limited statement provided by the Ethics Board.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: For purposes of § 7-21 {"Real property"} of this subtitle and § 7-22 {"Business entities"} of this subtitle, the following interests are attributable to and must be reported by the public servant.

para.heading: Certain interests held by spouse, etc.
para.text: An interest is attributable to the public servant if, at any time during the reporting period, it was:
held by a spouse, parent, child, or sibling of the public servant; and
directly or indirectly controlled by the public servant.

para.heading: Interests held by certain business entities.

para.text: An interest is attributable to the public servant if, at any time during the reporting period, it was held by a business entity in which an equity interest of 30% or more was held by or otherwise attributable under this section to the public servant.
This subsection does not limit:
the requirements of § 7-21 {"Real property"} of this subtitle to disclose real property interests held by entities in which the public servant holds an interest; or
the requirements of § 7-22 {"Business entities"} of this subtitle to disclose certain entities in which the public servant holds an interest.

para.heading: Interests held by certain trusts.
para.text: An interest is attributable to the public servant if, at any time during the reporting period, it was held by a trust or estate in which the public servant:
held a reversionary interest;
was a beneficiary; or
if a revocable trust, was a settlor.

annotations.annotation: Ordinance 19-287 amended paragraph (c)(1), effective February 25, 2020, to expand the reference to an equity interest “held” by the public servant to encompass an equity interest “held by or otherwise attributable under this section to” the public servant.

section.heading: Blind trusts.
section.text: For purposes of any of the disclosures required by this subtitle, interests held by a blind trust are not considered interests of the public servant making the statement if:

para.text: the blind trust is approved by the Ethics Board in accordance with rules and regulations adopted under this article; and
the blind trust is operated in compliance with those rules and regulations.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: The statement must include a schedule of each interest in real property that, at any time during the reporting period, was held by or, under § 7-17 {"Attributable interests"} of this subtitle, was attributable to the public servant, including each interest held in the name of a partnership, limited liability partnership, limited liability company, or other unincorporated entity in which an interest was held by or attributable to the public servant.

para.heading: Required specifics.
para.text: For each interest subject to this section, the schedule must include:
the nature of the property;
the property's location by street address, mailing address, or legal description;
the nature and extent of the interest held, including any conditions to and encumbrances on the interest;
the identity of each other person with an interest in the property;
the date and manner in which the interest was acquired;
the identity of the person from which the interest was acquired;
if the interest was acquired by purchase, the nature and amount of the consideration given for the interest;
if the interest was acquired in any other manner, the fair market value of the interest when acquired;
if any interest was transferred, in whole or in part, at any time during the reporting period:
a description of the interest transferred;
the nature and amount of the consideration received for the interest; and
the identity of the person to which the interest was transferred.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: The statement must include a schedule of each interest in any corporation, partnership, limited liability company, or any other business entity, whether or not that entity does business with or is regulated by the City, if, at any time during the reporting period, the interest was held by or, under § 7-17 {"Attributable interests"} of this subtitle, was attributable to the public servant.

para.heading: Required specifics.
para.text: For each interest subject to this section, the schedule must include:
the name and address of the principal office of the business entity;
subject to subsection (c) of this section, the nature and amount of the interest held, including any conditions to and encumbrances on the interest;
except as provided in subsection (d) of this section, if any interest was acquired during the reporting period:
the date and manner in which the interest was acquired;
the identity of the person from which the interest was acquired;
if the interest was acquired by purchase, the nature and amount of the consideration given for the interest; and
if the interest was acquired in any other manner, the fair market value of the interest when it was acquired; and
if any interest was transferred, in whole or in part, during the reporting period:
a description of the interest transferred;
the nature and amount of the consideration received for the interest; and
if known, the identity of the person to which the interest was transferred.
For an equity interest in a corporation, the reporting requirements of subsection (b)(2) of this section may be satisfied by reporting, instead of a dollar amount:
the number of shares held; and
unless the corporation's stock is publicly traded, the percentage of equity interest held.

For an equity interest in a partnership, limited liability company, or any other business entity, the reporting requirements of subsection (b)(2) of this section may be satisfied by reporting, instead of a dollar amount, the percentage of equity interest held.

para.heading: Reporting dividend reinvestments, etc.
para.text: For purposes of the reporting requirements of subsection (b)(3) of this section, only the manner of acquisition need be disclosed if:
the interest was acquired by dividend or dividend reinvestment and consists solely of additions to existing, publicly traded corporate interests; and
the total value of the acquisition is less than $500.
In this section, "significant gift" means, except as specified in paragraph (2) of this subsection:
any gift with a value of more than $20; and
any gift in a series of gifts with a cumulative value of $100 or more given by or on behalf of the same person during the reporting period.
"Significant gift" does not include any of the following, regardless of value:
a gift from a spouse, parent, child, or sibling;
a campaign contribution that is otherwise reported as required by law; or

tickets or free admission given to an elected official to attend a specific charitable, cultural, or political event, if given by the person sponsoring or conducting the event as a courtesy or ceremony to the office.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: The statement must include a schedule of each significant gift that was, at any time during the reporting period:
accepted by the public servant or by any other person at the direction of the public servant; and
given by or on behalf of, directly or indirectly, any person that the public servant knows or has reason to know was:
a lobbyist;
a person regulated by the City; or
a person doing business with the City.

para.heading: Required specifics.
para.text: For each gift subject to this section, the schedule must include:
the nature and value of the gift; and
the identity of the person from whom, or on behalf of whom, directly or indirectly, the gift was received.

para.heading: Section not an authorization.
para.text: Neither this section nor any disclosure made under it authorizes any gift that is not otherwise allowed by law.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: The statement must include a schedule of each office, directorship, salaried employment, and other similar interest not otherwise disclosed that was, at any time during the reporting period:
held by the public servant, by the public servant's spouse or child, or, if known to the public servant, by the public servant's parent or sibling,
in any business entity that was:
a lobbyist,
regulated by the City, or
doing business with the City.

para.heading: Directorships held by the public servant.
para.text: In addition to the requirements set forth in subsection (a) of this section, the statement must include each directorship held by the public servant in any business entity.

para.heading: Required specifics.
para.text: For each position or interest subject to this section, the schedule must include:
the name and address of the principal office of the business entity;
the title and nature of the position or interest;
the date when the position or interest began;
if applicable, the name of each agency with which the entity is doing business, by which it is regulated, or in connection with which it is a lobbyist;
if applicable, the nature of the entity's relationship to the City, which at a minimum must refer to the applicable criteria listed in subsection (a)(2) of this section; and
if the position or interest is held by someone other than the public servant, the identity of the individual who held the position or interest.

annotations.annotation: Subsection (b) was added by Ordinance 19-287, effective February 25, 2020.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: Except as specified in subsection (c) of this section, the statement must include a schedule of each debt that was, at any time during the reporting period, owed:
by the public servant or, if the public servant was involved in the transaction giving rise to the debt, by the public servant's spouse, parent, child, or sibling,
to any business entity that was:
a lobbyist;
regulated by the public servant's agency; or
doing business with the public servant's agency.

para.heading: Required specifics.
para.text: For each debt subject to this section, the schedule must include:
the identity of the person to whom the debt was owed;
the date the debt was incurred;
the amount owed at the end of the reporting period;
the terms of payment;
the extent to which the principal was increased or decreased during the reporting period; and
any security given.

para.heading: Exceptions.
para.text: This section does not apply to:
a retail credit account;
a retail installment sales account; or
a utility account.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: The statement must include a schedule of any spouse, parent, child, or sibling who was, at any time during the reporting period, employed by the City in any capacity.

para.heading: Required specifics.
para.text: For each family member subject to this section, the schedule must include:
the individual's name and relationship to the public servant; and
the agency and position in which the individual was employed.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: The statement must include a schedule that lists, for the public servant and for each of the public servant's spouse and children:
each place of compensated employment at any time during the reporting period; and
each business entity:
of which the public servant, spouse, or child was a sole or partial owner; and
from which, at any time during the reporting period, he or she received earned income.

para.heading: Required specifics.
para.text: For each source of income subject to this section, the schedule must include:
the name and address of the place of salaried employment or business entity;
for each family member, that individual's name and relationship to the public servant; and
if the individual's spouse is a lobbyist, any entity that has engaged the spouse for lobbying purposes.

section.heading: Sources of income - Substantial interests of elected officials.

para.heading: "Substantial interest" defined.
para.text: In this section, "substantial interest" means holding an equity interest of 30% or more in a business entity.

para.heading: Scope of section.
para.text: This section only applies to payments received from any person that the elected official knows or should know was:
a lobbyist;
a person regulated by the City; or
a person doing business with the City.

para.heading: Substantial interest in single entity.
para.text: If the elected official or the elected official's spouse has a substantial interest in a business entity, the statement must include the name and address of any person described in subsection (b) of this section who, during the reporting period, paid that entity:
$1,000 or more in the aggregate; or
an amount that in the aggregate constitutes 5% or more of the gross income of that entity, if the gross income of that entity is less than $20,000.

para.heading: Substantial interest in multiple entities.
para.text: If the elected official or the elected official's spouse has a substantial interest in multiple business entities, the statement must include the name and address of any person described in subsection (b) of this section, who during the reporting period, paid those entities:
$1,000 or more in the aggregate; or
an amount that in the aggregate constitutes 5% or more of the gross income of those entities, if the gross income of those business entities is less than $20,000.

para.heading: Confidential information.
para.text: Nothing in this section is meant to require the disclosure of any information that is otherwise confidential by law.

section.heading: Additional information.
section.text: The statement may include a schedule of additional interests or information that the public servant chooses to disclose.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: In this subtitle, the following terms have the meanings indicated.

para.heading: Compensation.
para.text: If lobbying is only part of a person's employment, "compensation" means a prorated amount of the person's total compensation, as defined in § 2-7 of this article, that is based on the time devoted by the person to lobbying compared to the time devoted to other employment duties.

para.heading: Executive action.
para.text: "Executive action" means any official action or nonaction that:
is taken by a public servant; and
is not legislative action, as defined in this section.
"Legislative action" means any official action or nonaction relating to:
any bill, resolution, nomination, appointment, report, or other matter within the jurisdiction of the City Council; or
any bill or resolution presented to the Mayor for approval or veto.
"Legislative action" includes:
introduction;
sponsorship;
consideration and debate;
amendment;
passage or defeat; and
approval or veto.

para.heading: Lobby.
para.text: "Lobby" means to do any act that requires registration under this subtitle.

para.heading: Reporting period.
para.text: "Reporting period" means all or any part of the period from January 1 of any year through December 31 of the same year during which a person is registered or required to be registered with the Ethics Board as a lobbyist.

section.heading: In general.
section.text: Except as otherwise specified in Part V {"Exemptions"} of this subtitle, a person who engages in any activity described in this Part II must register with the Ethics Board.

section.heading: Legislative lobbying.
section.text: A person must register if, during a reporting period, the person:

para.text: for the purpose of influencing any legislative action, communicates with a public servant; and
in furtherance of or in connection with all such communications for that or any other legislative action, and all activities relating to those communications:
expends $100 or more for gifts, including meals, beverages, or special events, to 1 or more public servants;
incurs any expenses of $500 or more; or
earns $2,500 or more in compensation.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: A person must register if, during a reporting period, the person:
for the purpose of influencing any executive action, communicates with a public servant; and

in furtherance of or in connection with all such communications for that or any other executive action, and all activities relating to those communications, expends $100 or more for gifts, including meals, beverages, or special events, to 1 or more public servants.

para.heading: Regulations; Executive Orders.
para.text: A person must register if, during a reporting period, the person:
for the purpose of influencing the development, adoption, issuance, or amendment of regulations or of an executive order, communicates with a public servant; and
in furtherance of or in connection with all such communications for that or any other executive action, and all activities relating to those communications:
expends $100 or more for gifts, including meals, beverages, or special events, to 1 or more public servants;
incurs any expenses of $500 or more; or
earns $2,500 or more in compensation.
A person must register if, during a reporting period, the person:
for the purpose of influencing executive action on a procurement contract that exceeds $50,000, communicates with a public servant; and
in furtherance of or in connection with all such communications for that or any other executive action, and all activities relating to those communications:
expends $100 or more for gifts, including meals, beverages, or special events, to 1 or more public servants; or
except as provided in paragraph (2) of this subsection, is compensated for his or her services.

Paragraph (1)(ii)(B) of this subsection does not apply to a bona fide salesperson or commercial selling agency employed or maintained by an employer for the purpose of soliciting or securing a procurement contract, as long as the person engages in no other acts during the reporting period that require registration.
A person must register if, during a reporting period, the person:
for the purpose of influencing executive action to secure for a business entity a grant or loan that exceeds $50,000, communicates with a public servant; and
in furtherance of or in connection with all such communications for that or any other executive action, and all activities relating to those communications:
expends $100 or more for gifts, including meals, beverages, or special events, to 1 or more public servants; or
except as provided in paragraph (2) of this subsection, is compensated for his or her services.
Paragraph (1)(ii)(B) of this subsection does not apply to either of the following, as long as the person engages in no other acts during the reporting period that require registration:
a bona fide full-time official or employee of a business entity that is seeking to secure a grant or loan; or
a person who is seeking a grant or loan for the purpose of locating, relocating, or expanding a business in or into the City.

section.heading: "Grass roots" lobbying.
section.text: A person must register if, during a reporting period, the person:

para.text: for the purpose of influencing any legislative or executive action, solicits others to communicate with a public servant; and

in furtherance of or in connection with that solicitation, expends $1,000 or more, including expenditures for salaries, contractual employees, postage, telecommunications services, electronic services, advertising, printing, or delivery services.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: Any person that engages a lobbyist for the purpose of lobbying must provide a written authorization for the lobbyist to act on the person's behalf.

para.heading: Contents.
para.text: The authorization must include:
the person's full legal name and business address;
the lobbyist's full legal name and business address;
the period during which the lobbyist is authorized to act; and
the legislative action, executive action, or other matter on which the lobbyist is authorized to act.

para.heading: Signature.
para.text: The authorization must be signed by:
the person on whose behalf the lobbyist is being authorized to act; or
if that person is a corporation, any authorized officer or agent of the corporation other than the lobbyist.

para.heading: Initial registration.
para.text: A lobbyist must register within 5 days after first engaging in any act that requires registration.

para.heading: Annual renewal.
para.text: A lobbyist must file a new registration on or before January 1 of each year if, on that date, the lobbyist is engaged in lobbying.

para.heading: Separate registration per principal.
para.text: A lobbyist who engages in lobbying on behalf of more than 1 person must file a separate registration for each person.

para.heading: Form.
para.text: The registration must be filed on the form the Ethics Board provides.

para.heading: Contents.
para.text: The registration must include the following information, as applicable:
the lobbyist's full legal name and business address;
the full legal name and business address of each other person that will be lobbying on the lobbyist's behalf;
the full legal name, address, and nature of business of the person on whose behalf the lobbyist is acting;

a statement of whether, because of the lobbyist's registration and reporting, the person on whose behalf the lobbyist is acting will be exempt from registration under § 8-33 {"Employer of reporting lobbyist"} of this subtitle; and

the identification, by formal designation, if known, of the legislative action, executive action, or other matter on which the lobbyist is acting or expects to act or on which the lobbyist has engaged or expects to engage another person to act.

para.heading: Written Authorization.
para.text: The registration must be accompanied by the written authorization required by § 8-11 {"Employer authorization required"} of this subtitle.

section.heading: Registration filing fee.
section.text: Each lobbying registration must be accompanied by a filing fee of $100. This fee shall be adjusted annually in accordance with the City Fee Policy and as approved by the Board of Estimates.

para.heading: Automatic termination.
para.text: Unless sooner terminated under subsection (b) of this section, each registration terminates on the earlier of:
the December 31 that first follows the registration's filing; or
the date specified in a written authorization filed under § 8-11 {"Employer authorization required"} of this subtitle.

para.heading: Termination by lobbyist.
para.text: A lobbyist may terminate the registration as of an earlier date than that specified in subsection (a) of this section if the lobbyist:
ceases all activity that requires registration;
after ceasing all activity, files a notice of termination with the Ethics Board; and
within 30 days after filing the notice, files all reports required by this subtitle.

para.heading: Required termination on appointment as public servant.

para.text: Except as provided in paragraph (2) of this subsection, if a lobbyist is or becomes subject to regulation under this article as a public servant, the lobbyist must:
immediately cease all activity that requires registration; and
terminate his or her registration in accordance with subsection (b) of this section within 30 days of becoming a public servant:
file a notice of termination with the Ethics Board; and
file all reports required by this subtitle.
Paragraph (1) of this subsection does not apply to a lobbyist appointed to an advisory body of limited duration.

annotation.text: The following Part IV is shown as amended by Ordinance 18-198 (Bill 18-230) to require the filing of semi-annual, rather than annual, lobbying reports and to require that these reports be posted on the Ethics Board’s website for public viewing. These changes, however, are subject to a special, delayed effective date. As described in the relevant provisions of Section 3(a) of Ord. 18-198

“The amendments made by this Ordinance to Part IV of Code Article 8, Subtitle 8, take effect ... on ... the 30th day after MOIT/BCIT has developed a viable, searchable online module that meets the criteria required by the Ethics Board and that will allow lobbyists to prepare and file their reports online, subject to the online payment of all attendant fees.”
Progress to date suggests that the required online module will be completed and available for public use in June or early July, 2019.

para.heading: Semi-annual reports required.
para.text: A lobbyist must file with the Ethics Board semi-annual activity reports for the reporting period for which the lobbyist is registered or required to be registered.
For each reporting period, these semi-annual reports must be filed as follows:
on or before July 31, covering the immediately preceding January 1 through June 30; and
on or before January 31, covering all of the immediately preceding January 1 through December 31.
A separate report must be filed for each person on whose behalf the lobbyist acted.
Each report must be:
filed on the form the Ethics Board provides; and
signed under oath or affirmation, subject to the penalties of perjury.
If the lobbyist is not an individual, then an authorized officer or agent of the lobbyist must sign the report.

section.heading: Contents – Registration information
section.text: Each report must include a complete, current statement of the information required by § 8-13(c) {"Registration: Contents"} of this subtitle.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: Except as provided in subsection (c) of this subsection, each report must include the total compensation paid to the lobbyist in connection with lobbying activities during the period to which that report applies, as specified in § 8-16(b)(1) of this subtitle.

para.heading: Prorated amounts.
para.text: If the compensation being reported is a prorated amount, it must be so labeled.

para.heading: Exceptions.
para.text: This section does not apply to:
expenses otherwise reported under other sections of this Part IV; or
salaries, compensation, and reimbursed expenses for the lobbyist's staff.

para.heading: Staff, research, and assistance.
para.text: Except as reported under § 8-18 {"Contents — Compensation"} of this subtitle, each report must include the total amount expended in connection with the lobbying activities during the period to which that report applies, as specified in § 8-16(b)(1) of this subtitle, for:
office expenses of the lobbyist; and
professional and technical research and assistance.

para.heading: Publications.
para.text: Each report must include the total amount expended in connection with the lobbying activities during the period to which that report applies, as specified in § 8-16(b)(1) of this subtitle, for publications that expressly encourage others to communicate with 1 or more public servants.

para.heading: Witnesses.
para.text: Each report must include:
the total amount expended in connection with lobbying activities for witnesses during the period to which that report applies, as specified in § 8-16(b)(1) of this subtitle;
the name of each witness; and
the fees and expenses paid to each.

Each report must include the total amount expended for each of the following during the period to which that report applies, as specified in § 8-16(b)(1) of this subtitle, whether or not expended in connection with lobbying activities:
meals and beverages for a public servant or the spouse, parent, child, or sibling of a public servant;
special events, including parties, dinners, athletic events, entertainment, and other functions, to which a public servant or the spouse, parent, child, or sibling of a public servant is invited;
food, lodging, or scheduled entertainment of a public servant or the spouse, parent, child, or sibling of a public servant while attending a meeting;

tickets or free admission for a public servant or the spouse, parent, child, or sibling of a public servant to attend a professional or intercollegiate sporting event or a charitable, cultural, or political event; and
other gifts to or for a public servant or the spouse, parent, child, or sibling of a public servant.
The lobbyist must report the name of any public servant or the spouse, parent, child, or sibling of a public servant who benefitted from:
expenses reported under paragraph (1)(i) of this subsection; or
expenses reported under paragraph (1)(iii) of this subsection, if more than $200 was expended for the benefit of the public servant, spouse, parent, child, or sibling.
Expenses reported under paragraph (1)(ii), (iii), and (iv) of this subsection must be itemized by:
the date and location of each event or activity; and
the total expense of the lobbyist for the event or activity.

para.heading: Other expenses.
para.text: Each report must include the total amount expended for all other expenses incurred in connection with the lobbying activities during the period to which that report applies, as specified in § 8 16(b)(1) of this subtitle.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: Except as provided in subsection (c) of this section, each report must include the name of each public servant or the spouse, parent, child, or sibling of a public servant to or for whom the lobbyist or any person on the lobbyist's behalf has given, during the reporting period, 1 or more gifts with a cumulative value of $150 or more, whether or not given in connection with lobbying activities.

para.heading: Itemization of certain gifts.
para.text: For reports under subsection (a) of this section, each gift made after the $150 cumulative value is met must be itemized by:
date;
beneficiary;
nature of gift; and
value of gift.

para.heading: Exception.
para.text: This section does not apply to gifts reported under § 8-19(d)(1)(ii) or (iii) of this subtitle.
This section applies to an individual who:
is a lobbyist under § 8-7 {"Legislative lobbying"} or § 8-8 {"Executive lobbying"} of this subtitle; and
engages in a business transaction with:
any of the following officials:
the Mayor;
the City Comptroller;
the President of the City Council;
a member of the City Council;
the head of any department; or
the head of any bureau or division within a department; or
any of the following related persons:
the spouse, parent, child, or sibling of an official listed in subitem (A);
a business entity in which an official listed in subitem (A) is a proprietor or partner; or
a business entity in which an official listed in subitem (A) has an ownership interest of 10% or more.
This section does not apply to:
an individual who is a lobbyist solely under § 8-9 {"'Grass roots' lobbying"} of this subtitle; or
the person who employs a lobbyist.

para.heading: Disclosure required.
para.text: Each report of a lobbyist subject to this section must disclose any business transaction or series of business transactions that:
was with a person listed in subsection (a)(1)(ii) of this section;
occurred during the reporting period; and
involved consideration of:
$1,000 or more for a single transaction; or
$5,000 or more for a series of transactions.

para.heading: Contents.
para.text: The disclosure required by this section must include:
the date or dates of the transaction or series of transactions;
the name and title of the official who was involved in the transaction or series of transactions;
the nature of the transaction or series of transactions; and
the nature and value of anything exchanged in the transaction or series of transactions.

section.heading: Supplemental reports.
section.text: The Ethics Board may require a lobbyist to file any additional or supplemental reports that the Board considers necessary.

section.heading: Reports to be public.
section.text: All reports filed under this subtitle are public documents and must be posted on the Ethics Board's website.

section.heading: General exemptions.
section.text: The following activities are exempt from regulation under this subtitle:

para.text: appearances as part of the official duties of an elected or appointed official or employee of the City, the State, the United States, any other state, or a political subdivision of any of them, to the extent that the appearance is not on behalf of any other person;
actions of a member of the news media, to the extent that the actions are in the ordinary course of gathering and disseminating news or making editorial comment to the general public;
representation of a bona fide religious organization, to the extent that the representation is for the purpose of protecting the right of its members to practice the doctrine of the organization; or

appearances as part of the official duties of an officer, director, member, or employee of an association engaged exclusively in representing the State, counties or municipal corporations, to the extent that the appearance is not in behalf of any other person.

para.heading: Appearances on request.
para.text: The following activities are exempt from regulation under this subtitle if the individual engages in no other acts during the reporting period that require registration:
appearances before the City Council, before a committee or subcommittee of the City Council, or before a City agency at the specific request of the body involved; or

appearances before the City Council, before a committee or subcommittee of the City Council, or before a City agency at the specific request of a lobbyist, if the witness notifies the body that he or she is testifying at the request of the lobbyist.

para.heading: Student activities.
para.text: An elementary, secondary, or pos-tsecondary school student or student organization that communicates as part of a course or student activity is not subject to the registration requirements of this subtitle based on the expense threshold of § 8-7 {"Legislative lobbying"} or § 8-8 {"Executive lobbying"} of this subtitle.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: A person that would otherwise be required to register and report under this subtitle need not do so if that person:
employs a lobbyist; and
reasonably believes that the lobbyist will:
register as required by this subtitle; and
timely report all expenses incurred in connection with that person's lobbying activities.

para.heading: Authorization still required.
para.text: A person exempt under subsection (a) of this section must still complete the authorization required by § 8-11 {"Employer authorization required"} of this subtitle.

para.heading: Exemption terminates on failure to report.
para.text: If the lobbyist fails to report the information when required by this subtitle, the person previously exempt under this subsection immediately becomes subject to the registration and reporting requirements of this subtitle.

para.heading: Legislative lobbying.
para.text: A lobbyist may not lobby on behalf of any person for compensation that is dependent in any way on:
the passage, enactment, or defeat of any legislation; or
any other contingency related to legislative action.

para.heading: Executive lobbying.
para.text: A lobbyist may not lobby on behalf of any person for compensation that is dependent in any way on:
the outcome of any executive action relating to the solicitation or securing of a procurement contract; or
any other contingency related to executive action.

section.heading: Gifts.
section.text: A lobbyist may not make a gift to a public servant, directly or indirectly:

para.text: if the lobbyist knows or has reason to know that the public servant's acceptance of the gift would violate Subtitle 6 {"Conflicts of Interest"}, Part IV {"Gifts"} of this article; or
if the gift is made as a result of a solicitation or facilitation that the lobbyist knows or has reason to know is prohibited by § 6-26(a)(3).

section.heading: Loans.
section.text: Unless in the ordinary course of the lobbyist's business as or for a banking institution, banking association, mortgage broker or lender, sales finance company, or other similarly regulated financial or lending institution, a lobbyist may not make or facilitate the making of any loan of money, goods, or services to a public servant.

section.heading: Fund raisers.
section.text: A lobbyist who is an individual may not engage in any charitable fund-raising activity at the request of a public servant, including soliciting a charitable contribution, transmitting the solicitation of a charitable contribution, or transmitting a charitable contribution.

section.heading: "Bell ringing".
section.text: A lobbyist may not initiate or encourage the introduction of legislation for the purpose of opposing that legislation.

section.heading: Requesting endorsement.
section.text: A lobbyist may not ask a public servant to recommend to a potential client the lobbyist's services or the services of any other lobbyist.

para.heading: Veracity required.
para.text: While engaging in lobbying activities a lobbyist, or an individual who expects she or he will soon be required to register as a lobbyist, may not knowingly make to a public servant a statement of material fact that relates to the lobbying activity and that the lobbyist knows to be false.

para.heading: Duty to identify self and clients.
para.text: While engaging in lobbying activities a lobbyist, or an individual who expects she or he will soon be required to register as a lobbyist, must, in any interaction with a public servant:
affirmatively identify themselves as a lobbyist; and
identify the person on whose behalf they are lobbying.

section.heading: Retention required.
section.text: Any person required to file a report, statement, or other item under this article must obtain and, for the period specified in § 9-2 {"Retention period"} of this subtitle, retain all accounts, bills, receipts, books, papers, documents, and other records necessary to complete and substantiate the report, statement, or other item.

section.heading: Retention period.
section.text: The person must retain the records required by § 9-1 {"Retention required"} of this subtitle for at least 3 years from:

para.text: the date on which the report, statement, or other item was filed; or
if the report, statement, or other item was not filed, the date by which it was required to be filed.

section.heading: Inspection of records.
section.text: On request and reasonable notice, the records required by § 9-1 {"Retention required"} of this subtitle must be made available to the Ethics Board or the City Solicitor for inspection.

section.heading: In general.
section.text: If, after considering a complaint brought under Subtitle 5 {"Complaints"} of this article, the Ethics Board determines that the respondent has violated any provision of this article, the Board may take any 1 or more of the following actions:

para.text: issue an order directing the respondent to cease and desist from the violation;
issue a reprimand;
refer the matter to the appropriate official or other authority for other disciplinary action authorized by law, including censure or removal; or
seek judicial relief or other enforcement action under this subtitle.

section.heading: Lobbying violations.
section.text: If, after considering a complaint brought under Subtitle 5 {"Complaints"} of this article, the Ethics Board determines that the respondent has violated any provision of Subtitle 8 {"Lobbying"} of this article, the Board may take any 1 or more of the following actions:

para.text: require a respondent who is a lobbyist to file any additional reports or information that reasonably relates to the information required by Subtitle 8;
impose a civil penalty of not more than $1,000 for each violation;
prohibit a respondent from engaging in any lobbying activities intended to influence any City public servant on any matter for a period of not more than 3 years; or
take any other action authorized by § 9-4 {"In general"} of this subtitle.

para.text: The Ethics Board may assess a late fee of $10 per day, up to an aggregate maximum of$1,000 per overdue statement, on any public servant who does not file a complete financial disclosure statement on or before the date it is due.
Within 30 days after any late fee is assessed under this subsection, a public servant may file a written request with the Ethics Board to reduce or waive the fee for good cause.

para.heading: Notice to public servant.
para.text: If a public servant has failed to file a complete financial disclosure statement within 5 days of the date required under this article, the Ethics Board must notify the public servant in writing of the public servant's noncompliance and of the potential consequences under this section for continued noncompliance.

If a public servant has failed to file a complete financial disclosure statement within 15 days of the date required under this article, the Ethics Board must notify the public servant in writing of the public servant's continued noncompliance and the potential consequences of further continued noncompliance.
A copy of the notice sent under this subsection must be sent to:
the public servant's agency head;
the Director of Human Resources; and
the City Solicitor.

para.heading: Referral to the Office of Inspector General.

para.text: If a public servant has failed to file a complete financial disclosure statement within 30 days of the date required under this article, the Ethics Board must refer the matter in writing to the Office of the Inspector General for investigation.
A copy of the Board's referral made under this subsection must be sent to:
the public servant;
the public servant's agency head;
the Director of Human Resources; and
the City Solicitor.

If a public servant has failed to file a complete financial disclosure statement within 60 days of the date required under this article, the Ethics Board may refer the matter to the public servant's agency head, the Director of Human Resources, and the City Solicitor, with a recommendation that the public servant be suspended from office without pay until the financial disclosure statement is filed.
A referral for suspension must include copies of the notices to the public servant required under this section.
Regardless of whether any action is taken against the public servant, a copy of the Board's referral must be included in the public servant's agency personnel file.
This subsection does not apply to elected officials.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: The Ethics Board may file a petition in Circuit Court, on behalf of the Mayor and City Council, to compel compliance with or seek other relief under this article.

para.heading: Remedies cumulative.
para.text: The remedies authorized in this article are cumulative, and the court may grant all or part of the relief sought.

section.heading: Relief generally.
section.text: In an action brought under § 9-6 {"Petition to court"} of this subtitle, the court may compel compliance with this article:

para.text: by issuing an order to cease and desist from a violation; or
by granting other injunctive relief.

para.heading: Penalty authorized.
para.text: In an action brought under § 9-6 {"Petition to court"} of this subtitle, the court may impose a civil penalty of up to $1,000 for any violation of this article.

para.heading: Each day a separate offense.
para.text: For this purpose, each day on which a violation occurs is a separate offense.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: Except as provided in subsection (b) of this section, in an action brought under § 9-6 {"Petition to court"} of this subtitle, the court may void an official act of a public servant if:
the public servant had a conflict of interest that is prohibited by this article;
the act arose from or concerned the subject matter of the conflict;
the proceeding was brought within 90 days after the act occurred; and
the court determines that the conflict had an impact on the act.
The court may not void any contract previously approved by the Board of Estimates without the express consent of the Board of Estimates.
The court may not void any official act that:
appropriates public funds;
levies a tax; or
provides for the issuance of a bond, note, or other evidence of public obligation.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: Except as provided in § 9-12 {"Exceptions"} of this subtitle, the Board of Estimates may void a contract with the City if:
a public servant had a conflict of interest that is prohibited by this article;
the contract arose from or concerned the subject matter of the conflict; and
the Board determines that the conflict had an impact on the contract.

para.heading: Scope.
para.text: In taking action under this section, the Board of Estimates may void a contract:
in whole or in part; and
on the terms and conditions that the Board sets.

section.heading: Exceptions.
section.text: The Board of Estimates may not void any contract under this subtitle that provides for the issuance of a bond, note, or other evidence of public obligation.

section.heading: Persons other than elected officials.
section.text: In addition to any other penalty imposed under this article, if the Ethics Board finds that a public servant, other than an elected official, has violated a provision of this article:

para.text: the public servant may be removed or subjected to other disciplinary action by the appropriate authority; and
if the public servant is subject to a Board or court order that directs compliance, the public servant may not be paid any salary or other compensation pending full compliance with the order.

section.heading: Elected officials.
section.text: If the Ethics Board finds that an elected official has violated a provision of this article, the Board must report its findings to the Mayor and the City Council for appropriate action.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: If, while considering a complaint, the Ethics Board finds that there are reasonable grounds to believe that the respondent has committed a criminal offense, the Board must promptly refer the matter to the appropriate prosecuting authority.

para.heading: Evidence.
para.text: The Ethics Board must make available to the prosecuting authority all pertinent evidence under its control.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: Any person who knowingly violates a provision of Subtitle 8 {"Lobbying"} of this article, or fails to comply with an administrative sanction imposed under § 9-5 {"Lobbying violations"} of this subtitle, is guilty of a misdemeanor and, on conviction, is subject to a fine of not more than $1,000 or imprisonment of not more than 12 months or both.

para.heading: Officers and partners.
para.text: If the person is a business or other entity, each officer or partner of the entity who knowingly authorizes or participates in the violation is guilty of a misdemeanor and, on conviction, is subject to the penalty specified in subsection (a) of this section.
